awd_titl_txt: Enhancing the Instrumentation and Control Technician Program: Instrumentation Acquisition
awd_abstract_narration:
Instrumentation and controls technicians are important in the nation's advanced manufacturing industry. These technicians troubleshoot and repair components of production lines that keep manufacturing processes running smoothly. Currently, industries in Northeast Florida face a shortage of skilled instrumentation and controls technicians. This problem is exacerbated by the predicted turnover of approximately one third of the manufacturing workforce over the next five years because of retirements. Advanced manufacturing industries regularly redesign and streamline production lines, including increasing the use of automated processes. As a result, there is an ongoing expansion of the skills that instrumentation and control technicians need to do their jobs. To address this need, Florida State College at Jacksonville (Florida) will develop a new Instrumentation and Controls concentration for its existing Associate of Science degree in Engineering Technology. The project team will work closely with industry partners to: modify the curriculum; obtain industry-standard equipment for laboratory exercises; and provide problem-based, hands-on learning experiences for students. The project will examine and contribute to what is known about hands-on instrumentation training, support effective strategies for recruiting underrepresented students to the instrumentation and controls field, and help fill the critical need for these technicians in Northeast Florida.

This project will develop and modify five courses to create a concentration in Instrumentation and Controls for the existing associate degree program. The courses will include hands-on simulation laboratory activities that engage students in the types of processes they will encounter on the job. The activities will give students access to new technologies, and increased practice to master essential industrial instrumentation skills. Authentication assessments and proper procedures for handling sensors and instrumentation will be central components of the curricular modifications. Laboratory tasks will emphasize the development of skills required to manage, operate, calibrate, and troubleshoot equipment. These tasks will also focus on enhancing knowledge associated with experimental, quality, and safety procedures. The project will foster technician skills training using a developmental curriculum that includes embedded and stacked credentials. Students' self-efficacy, sense of belonging, and career awareness related to advanced manufacturing will be measured. The result will be used to document the impact of the courses and lab activities on student learning and preparation for the workforce. Outreach activities will be conducted with area high schools to promote awareness of and career interest in instrumentation and controls technology. The project will emphasize involvement of students from underrepresented and underserved populations, to encourage diversity of the workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Enhancing the Instrumentation and Control Technician Program: Instrumentation Acquisition was a $499,655 National Science Foundation (NSF ID 1801140) center grant.

 

The projects goal was to develop and modify five courses to create a concentration in Instrumentation and Controls for the existing associate degree program. The courses include hands-on simulation laboratory activities.

 

A large portion of the grant was used to purchase state-of-the-art, instrumentation training equipment. The equipment chosen was based on the advice of the industry advisement panel that was developed specially for this project.

 

Dr. Angela Blackmon of Innovative Learning Center, LLC served as the external evaluator.

 

This project was initiated by former employee, Bill Allen, Director of Development for FSCJ Works, even before FSCJ applied for the NSF grant.  Mr. Allen received a request from a local industry (Rayonier Advanced Materials) for maintenance technicians with experience in instrumentation. Mr. Allen proceeded to contact other industries to determine if similar needs existed throughout the community.

 

 

Goal 1 - Results

 

Objective 1.1 -  Modify 5 courses

FSCJ modified 5 courses based on the Florida curriculum frame works and in coordination with the equipment and software purchased

 

Objective 1.2 – Launch classes

FSCJ launched all 5 courses by the end of year 3.

 

Objective 1.3 -  Create ICT BILT team

The I & CT roundtable morphed with the Manufacturing BILT and continues to function in guiding the curriculum.

 

Objective 1.4 - Enroll 120 students in I & C tract

 

This goal was not met. Over the term of the grant FSCJ had 104 students complete at least 1 or more instrumentation classes. Of that 35 students were dual-enrollment students from Englewood High.

 

 

Objective 1.5 - Increase numbers of underrepresented populations

 

This goal was partially met. As evident in Attachment 1, in the Spring semesters (where FSCJ offers most of the Instrumentation classes, females comprised about 34% of the students.

This is compared to less than 5% prior to 2020. In the same spring semesters non-white students averaged 48.3% of the student population, compared to 45% college wide, and an increase of 3.3% prior to 2020.

 

Goal 2  - Results

 

Objective 2.1 – Acquire simulation and lab equipment

 

Partnering primarily with Bluegrass Educational Technologies, FSCJ identified and acquired 4 pieces of training equipment. These included:

 

Festo 6090 (2) - Flow and Level Process Control Trainers

Festo 3531 – Pulp/Paper Process Training System

Festo 3531 PlantPAx Distributed Control System

Festo 5562 MecLab Training Package

 

 

Objective 2.2 – Complete face-to-face faculty and lab managers in-service

 

Though affected by the pandemic and shifting faculty, there were 2 faculty in-services conducted for the Festo equipment, as well as training on Simtronics and the OnSyte waste water plant.

 

Objective 2.3  - Train 10 faculty members and industry representatives on the I&C simulation equipment twice per semester throughout the project cycle.

 

This goal was not met. 3 faculty members (3/4 of the full time staff) and 1 lab manager were trained on the equipment.

 

Objective 2.4 -  Provide teaching and learning experiences to 60 students and 60 ICT professionals or incumbent workers.

This goal was partially met. Over the term of the grant FSCJ had 167 students complete at least 1 instrumentation classes.

 

 

Lessons Learned

 

Despite not meeting all of the projected goals, there were many lessons learned in the development of this project.

 

1) Start with a team that is invested in the project

 

The initial planning team for this project was a former dean, a program director (who had no experience in Instrumentation) and a foundation marketing manager. Although they did a good job assembling the roundtable of industry partners, they did not include any faculty until much later in the project.

 

Equipment was selected without faculty input, and without sufficient investigation as to what other colleges were using in their I & C labs. As a result 2 of the more expensive pieces of lab equipment have limited use in the day to day training.

 

Although we got a lot of initial support from industry for the program, the follow through was less than adequate. 2 of the 3 initial committed donations never materialized. Despite numerous attempts to encourage industries to take advantage of training opportunities, there were no trainings scheduled. The Career Education/Workforce Development needed to be more involved in the marketing portion of the grant.

 

The department needs to be fully staffed and the faculty needs to be fully invested. As a department, the Advanced Manufacturing had 2 deans and 1 interim dean during the span of the project. This lack of stable leadership, did not put sufficient pressure on the faculty to complete all the goals of the project. In addition, the faculty in place has had a teaching overload every semester during this project. Asking them to take on more was unrealistic.

 


Last Modified: 12/04/2022
Modified by: Alan Zube

Enhancing the Instrumentation and Control Technician Program: Instrumentation Acquisition was a $499,655 National Science Foundation (NSF ID 1801140) center grant.

 

The projects goal was to develop and modify five courses to create a concentration in Instrumentation and Controls for the existing associate degree program. The courses include hands-on simulation laboratory activities.

 

A large portion of the grant was used to purchase state-of-the-art, instrumentation training equipment. The equipment chosen was based on the advice of the industry advisement panel that was developed specially for this project.

 

Dr. Angela Blackmon of Innovative Learning Center, LLC served as the external evaluator.

 

This project was initiated by former employee, Bill Allen, Director of Development for FSCJ Works, even before FSCJ applied for the NSF grant.  Mr. Allen received a request from a local industry (Rayonier Advanced Materials) for maintenance technicians with experience in instrumentation. Mr. Allen proceeded to contact other industries to determine if similar needs existed throughout the community.

 

 

Goal 1 - Results

 

Objective 1.1 -  Modify 5 courses

FSCJ modified 5 courses based on the Florida curriculum frame works and in coordination with the equipment and software purchased

 

Objective 1.2 – Launch classes

FSCJ launched all 5 courses by the end of year 3.

 

Objective 1.3 -  Create ICT BILT team

The I & CT roundtable morphed with the Manufacturing BILT and continues to function in guiding the curriculum.

 

Objective 1.4 - Enroll 120 students in I & C tract

 

This goal was not met. Over the term of the grant FSCJ had 104 students complete at least 1 or more instrumentation classes. Of that 35 students were dual-enrollment students from Englewood High.

 

 

Objective 1.5 - Increase numbers of underrepresented populations

 

This goal was partially met. As evident in Attachment 1, in the Spring semesters (where FSCJ offers most of the Instrumentation classes, females comprised about 34% of the students.

This is compared to less than 5% prior to 2020. In the same spring semesters non-white students averaged 48.3% of the student population, compared to 45% college wide, and an increase of 3.3% prior to 2020.

Objective 2.1 – Acquire simulation and lab equipment

 

Partnering primarily with Bluegrass Educational Technologies, FSCJ identified and acquired 4 pieces of training equipment. These included:

 

Festo 6090 (2) - Flow and Level Process Control Trainers

Festo 3531 – Pulp/Paper Process Training System

Festo 3531 PlantPAx Distributed Control System

Objective 2.2 – Complete face-to-face faculty and lab managers in-service

 

Though affected by the pandemic and shifting faculty, there were 2 faculty in-services conducted for the Festo equipment, as well as training on Simtronics and the OnSyte waste water plant.

 

Objective 2.3  - Train 10 faculty members and industry representatives on the I&C simulation equipment twice per semester throughout the project cycle.

 

This goal was not met. 3 faculty members (3/4 of the full time staff) and 1 lab manager were trained on the equipment.

 

Objective 2.4 -  Provide teaching and learning experiences to 60 students and 60 ICT professionals or incumbent workers.

This goal was partially met. Over the term of the grant FSCJ had 167 students complete at least 1 instrumentation classes.

 

 

Lessons Learned

 

Despite not meeting all of the projected goals, there were many lessons learned in the development of this project.

 

1) Start with a team that is invested in the project

 

The initial planning team for this project was a former dean, a program director (who had no experience in Instrumentation) and a foundation marketing manager. Although they did a good job assembling the roundtable of industry partners, they did not include any faculty until much later in the project.

 

Equipment was selected without faculty input, and without sufficient investigation as to what other colleges were using in their I & C labs. As a result 2 of the more expensive pieces of lab equipment have limited use in the day to day training.

 

Although we got a lot of initial support from industry for the program, the follow through was less than adequate. 2 of the 3 initial committed donations never materialized. Despite numerous attempts to encourage industries to take advantage of training opportunities, there were no trainings scheduled. The Career Education/Workforce Development needed to be more involved in the marketing portion of the grant.

 

The department needs to be fully staffed and the faculty needs to be fully invested. As a department, the Advanced Manufacturing had 2 deans and 1 interim dean during the span of the project. This lack of stable leadership, did not put sufficient pressure on the faculty to complete all the goals of the project. In addition, the faculty in place has had a teaching overload every semester during this project. Asking them to take on more was unrealistic.
